text: with modern politics with the
circumstances of my resignation it isn't
really possible to be a proper backbench
MP as a former prime minister I think
everything you do will become a big
distraction and a big diversion from
what the government needs to do for our
country and I support to resume I think
she's got off to a great start I think
she can be a strong Prime Minister for
our country
and I don't want to be that distraction
I want Whitney to have a new MP who can
play a full part in parliamentary and
political life without being a
distraction I want to thank everybody
here in West Oxfordshire who've been so
supportive it has been a great honor and
privilege to serve this area and to
serve these brilliant people I'm going
to go on living locally I'll go on
supporting the local causes and local
charities that make this such a great
place in our country but obviously I'm
gonna have to start to build a life
outside Westminster I hope I'll continue
to contribute in terms of public service
and of course contribute to this country
that I love so much
now you could continue supporting to
resume and the new government from the
back benches that is possible by
resigning in the way that you are today
you are leaving yourself open to the
charge that you are snubbing the Prime
Minister you cannot support everything
that she is trying to do well I spoke to
Theresa May and she was very
understanding about this decision I
support her I support what she's doing
she's got off to a cracking start
obviously I'm going to have my own views
about different issues people would know
that and that's really the point as a
former prime minister it is very
difficult I think to sit as a
backbencher
and not be an enormous diversion and
distraction from what the government's
doing I don't want to be that
distraction I want Whitney to have an MP
that can play a full role in
parliamentary and political life in a
way that I think I would find very
difficult if not impossible one of the
views that you've articulated very
clearly and very often over the last
decade or so is your opposition to the
expansion of grammar schools therefore
by resigning two or three days after
Theresa May in that speech announced she
wanted a return to grammar schools in
England rather suggests you feel like
you couldn't support that particular
policy that this decision has got
nothing to do with any one individual
issue
the timing in that way I promise is
coincidental but it goes to a bigger
picture really which is whatever the
issue as a former Prime Minister being a
backbench MP I think it is difficult
just not to be the distraction the
diversion and therefore build a sort of
reputation for yourself in politics that
I don't really want to have I wish her
well I wish the government well you know
in a way there's a link to the decision
to resign as Prime Minister the country
made a decision a decision I advised
against but nonetheless the decisions
been made I want the government to
successfully pursue that decision and to
get it right and I think that as a
result actually not being a backbencher
but leaving Parliament is the right
thing to do can I ask you very straight
do you or do you not support the
expansion of grammar schools as
articulated by Tereza May last week oh I
think there's very many good things in
the policy we actually when I was Prime
Minister agreed to the expansion of
grammar schools in areas where they
already were we set up six forms that
were selective in our big cities as free
schools there lots of merit in the
policy but frankly I don't want to get
into the where's and why force of this
individual policy even what you've said
about grammar schools it rather suggests
you simply do not support their
expansion you've called them sheep and
goats and everything else over the last
10 years you were urged to expand them
you haven't you're now leaving rather
suggest you don't support it well no I
think that's not a fair reflection of
what we did we did actually allow the
expansion of grammar schools in areas
that have them and we did set up
selective SiC forms particularly in our
big cities and as I say I think there's
some merit in the policy that's being
put forward my announcement today is not
about grammar schools there's no
connection with grammar schools it's
purely one of timing my view is as I've
said I don't want to be the distraction
and diversion that I think a former
Prime Minister inevitably is on the back
benches so it's with a heavy heart
because I love this part of the world I
love being an MP I'm going to go on
living here being a constituency MP is a
great and fulfilling job but I've come
to the conclusion that actually the best
thing is to stand down and that's why
I'm making the announcement today
finally on your legacy Mr Cameron you
wanted to be the Prime Minister that was
remembered for reforming the
Conservative Party making it electable
reforming the economy introducing gay
marriage you will admit now that
you you will be remembered mostly for
taking this country out of the European
Union well I'm sure I will be remembered
for keeping that pledge to hold a
referendum when many people thought that
promise would never be kept but I hope
people will also look back at the 11
years I was leader of the Conservative
Party in six years as Prime Minister our
country as a time when we did create a
stronger economy a thousand people found
work for every day I was Prime Minister
and we did make some important social
reforms some of which you mentioned and
the Conservative Party went from being
in the doldrums and getting beaten to
being a modernizing winning force in
British politics but the historians will
have to work all that out I always see
now I'm going to be looking at a new
life but a new life
many 49 I hope I can still contribute in
terms of public service and contribute
to our country just quickly what is that
new life do you have plans presumably
it's something lucrative that you've got
lined up what is the new life that you
will do now you're no longer Prime
Minister well I haven't made firm
decisions I need to look at all of that
the only firm decision I've made is to
leave the House of Commons and stop
being an MP as I say with a heavy heart
because I've loved the job but I don't
think it works for a former prime
minister who resigned in my
circumstances and with all the new
government needs to do but issues for
the future other side them in the future
and hopefully as I say continue to make
some service and some public service
contribution to this country I want to
continue campaigning on the local
national and indeed international issues
that were part of my prime ministership
where I think we made some good progress
there's still a lot more to be done
Prime Minister David Cameron faster
thank you
